data.title: Shader not compiling with SM4.0 syntax.
Update MonoGame to support service dependencies
data.body:
This updates MonoGame to support services dependencies in Protobuild.  This was originally developed to address https://github.com/hach-que/Protobuild/issues/33, although I didn't have time then to update MonoGame or cocas2d-xna to support the new functionality.

Primarily this functionality separates the idea of a platform (which encapsulates platform-specific code and platform-specific project structures) and the idea of different APIs (or backends) as services.

For example, on Windows, you have the option of using 3 different graphics implementations:
- DirectX
- OpenGL
- Angle

These are currently exposed as Windows, WindowsGL and Angle respectively.  However, this setup does not work for consumers of MonoGame (who consume it as a Protobuild library).  The most direct example is that if someone wanted to include platform-specific code in their game, but use the Angle graphics API in MonoGame, they currently have no way of doing so when using MonoGame as a submodule.

Longer term, this also allows MonoGame to have multiple graphics APIs on mobile platforms; currently if you were to create an `iOSMetal` platform, it wouldn't be treated as iOS in terms of the project format generated.  Service dependencies keep these two concerns separate, so that a (potential) Metal-based graphics API could be enabled with `--enable MetalGraphics` when generating the projects.

To this end, the graphics and audio APIs have been exposed as services, such as `OpenGLGraphics`.  `WindowsGL` and `Angle` platforms have appropriate settings such that they work as they do currently.  Now when consuming MonoGame as a Protobuild submodule, and wanting to use an alternate graphics API, users can add the following to their game project:

```
<Dependencies>
  <Uses Name="MonoGame.Framework/OpenGLGraphics">
    <Platforms>Windows</Platforms>
  </Uses>
</Dependencies>
```

And the OpenGL API will be used by MonoGame when the user generates their projects for `Windows` (without using the `WindowsGL` platform).

(I've also removed the `Protobuild.sh` and `Protobuild.command` files as per discussion in https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/2966; the appropriate way to start Protobuild from the graphical UI on non-Windows platforms is to associate the `.exe` file type in your OS with Mono)

Content items now have a property 'Asset Name': the name given to the output/copied file.
Importing a contentproj will now import the 'Asset Name' of content items.

data.title: Set SamplerState.GraphicsDevice to null on reset
data.body:
The predefined SamplerState are statically initialized on first access
and their GraphicsDevice property set when Activate() is called.
However, SamplerState.GraphicsDevice is never cleared when the
GraphicsDevice is disposed. This leads to an assertion when a
SamplerState is re-activated on a new GraphicsDevice.

This PR adds a static SamplerState.PlatformReset() method that is
invoked when a GraphicsDevice is disposed, allowing SamplerStates to be
re-initialized when activated on a new GraphicsDevice.

data.title: Fix a crash bug in BeforeRun()
data.body:
The mouse update function uses a _form field after it has been disposed, resulting in a NRE. This PR ensures that disposed Forms are correctly removed from the list of windows, which prevents the crash.

It also locks the Form collection to protect against a potential race condition (open a new Form while disposing an existing one.)

data.title: VideoPlayer does not change state to MediaState.Stopped when the video finishes
data.body:
In XNA once the video reaches the end the state automatically switches to MediaState.Stopped

In the MonoGame source MediaState.Stopped is only ever set if you explicitly call the Stop() method or after construction of the video player

We considered this as a workaround:

```
_videoPlayer.PlayPosition >= _splashVideo.Duration
```

However it appears PlayPosition is not guaranteed to make it all the way to duration so you have to add fudge factors which isn't very practical.

e.g.
    _splashVideo.Duration - _videoPlayer.PlayPosition <= new TimeSpan(0, 0, 0, 0, 50)

I also have some recollection of MediaPlayer on XNA on Windows having perf issues if you polled certain properties so maybe reading PlayPosition is not a great work around if you want shared code.

data.title: Pipeline tool/mgcb does not support asset renaming
data.body:
XNA allows an asset name to be specified in the content project which is used instead of the truncated filename for the asset

e.g. you can have a file called 
MyMusic (16-bit).mp3

With an asset name of 
ThemeSong

And the resultant file will be ThemeSong.xnb not My Music (16-bit).xnb

We've worked around it by renaming the file for now but it would be nice to support that feature.

data.title: Vertex texture fetch, skeleton meshes without animations, Pipeline Tool changes
data.body:
*Adding support for vertex texture fetch to Windows (Direct3D 11) target. This code should theoretically also work for OpenGL, but it cannot be tested due to the currently-used version of MojoShader not supporting texture fetch instructions in vertex shaders.

*Support for importing skeleton meshes that don't have animations in the file. This is useful for having separate files for the mesh and the animations

*Adding functionality to the Pipeline Tool to add all files from a folder in one step.

*Pipeline Tool shows exception info from MGCB in the output pane

*Propagating some fullscreen flags further down the line (as fullscreen support is not fully implemented, you may want to skip this one)

*You may also want to skip the changes to the references for the Yeti media projects. I found them necessary to compile, iirc.

data.title: Fix for RunOneFrame() mouse was not updating.
data.body: Since RunOneFrame doesn't use the RunLoop, it doesn't get registered in that case.  So I moved the registration to creation, and unregister on dispose.

data.title: Implemented GraphicsDevice.Reset, Windows/DirectX only.
data.body:
Does the same thing as GraphicsDeviceManager.ApplyChanges within its Windows/DirectX block.
The common situation this is used is for a tool that needs to do xna rendering on a single control and doesn't even have a game/graphicsdevicemanager.

data.title: Exposing API for easily parsing the MGCB format
data.body:
The goal in this change is to allow other tools to understand the MGCB format by exposing PipelineProjectParser.
Most of the file changes below are removing unnecessary references to the IController type, which is something very specific to the PipelineTool, and cannot be made public.
Note that this PR does not in any way affect the behavior of the PipelineTool. All that happened was three classes went from internal to public.
